text: Lafayette talks to Press in his presentation as a Valencia BC player. Oliver Lafayette (born May 6, 1984) is an American-born Croatian professional basketball player who last played for Igokea of the ABA League. Standing at , he plays at the point guard and shooting guard positions. ==High school and college career== Lafayette attended Capitol High School in Baton Rouge, Louisiana and led the basketball team to a 29–3 record his senior year. Lafayette attended first Blinn College and Brown Mackie College before transferring to the University of Houston. At Houston during his junior year, Lafayette started 30 of 31 games and earned 2nd team all Conference USA while finishing third in scoring in C-USA with a 15.7 points per game average. During his senior year in 2006–07, Lafayette averaged 14.3 points, 5.9 rebounds and 3.1 assists per game. He also majored in sociology.Oliver Lafayette Player Bio UH Cougars ==Professional career== Lafayette played with the Fort Wayne Mad Ants during the 2009–10 season in the NBA Development League. With the Mad Ants, the guard started 42 of 48 games and averaged 17.1 points, 6.5 assists and 1.8 steals in 35.3 minutes per game.Celtics Sign Fort Wayne's Oliver Lafayette NBA.com, April 14, 2010 On April 14, 2010, Lafayette signed with the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association and appeared in one game with the team in which he scored 7 points. According to research by STATS LLC, those 7 points are an NBA record for most points scored in a career of exactly one game played. Upon playing with the Celtics, Lafayette became the 23rd former Houston Cougar to play in the NBA.Former Guard Oliver Lafayette Makes NBA Debut with Celtics on Wednesday uhcougars.com, April 15, 2010 On October 13, 2010, Lafayette signed with Partizan Belgrade in Serbia,Partizan Mt:s grabs Lafayette at point guard but the contract was terminated in November.Partizan: Lafayette out, Jerrells in In December 2010, Lafayette practiced with the Fort Wayne Mad Ants, his former team. He was going to sign with the Mad Ants once he was officially released from Partizan Belgrade.Lafayette to return to Mad Ants roster news- sentinel.com, December 15, 2010 After averaging 16.4 points per game with the Mad Ants, he signed a four-month contract with the Turkish team Beşiktaş.Besiktas sign Oliver LaFayette But due to health problems, his contract was dropped.Beşiktaş Cola Turka'da şok gelişme In February 2011, Lafayette signed with Maccabi Ashdod in Israel.Maccabi Ashdod tabs Oliver LaFayette On October 5, 2011 he signed a one-year contract with Asseco Prokom Gdynia in Poland.Asseco Prokom Gdynia lands Oliver Lafayette In January 2012, Lafayette signed with Anadolu Efes Istanbul for the remainder of the 2011–12 season.Anadolu Efes tabs Lafayette Later that year, he joined Žalgiris Kaunas.ZALGIRIS adds Lafayette, brings back Juskevicius He signed with Valencia Basket in the offseason in 2013.VALENCIA BASKET lands Lafayette On June 22, 2014, he signed a two-year deal with Olympiacos Piraeus. On June 29, 2015, he parted ways with Olympiacos. On July 9, 2015, he signed with the Italian club Emporio Armani Milano. On July 18, 2016, Lafayette signed with Spanish team Unicaja. In April 2017, Lafayette won his second EuroCup with Unicaja after beating Valencia BC in the Finals. On July 31, 2017, Lafayette signed with Italian club Virtus Bologna.Virtus Bologna signs Oliver Lafayette On November 13, 2018, Lafayette signed with Bosnian club Igokea. ==International career== The Croatian Basketball Federation asked for permission to give Oliver Lafayette a Croatian citizenship for sports interest, which the Croatian Olympic Committee approved. Lafayette was awarded with a Croatian passport and represented Croatia at the 2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup. ==Overseas Elite== In the summer of 2017, Lafayette joined two-time The Basketball Tournament defending champion Overseas Elite. On August 3, 2017, Blair's team, Overseas Elite won its third straight The Basketball Tournament championship with an 86-83 victory over Team Challenge ALS on ESPN. ==Career statistics== ===NBA=== ====Regular season==== |- | align="left" | | align="left" | Boston | 1 || 0 || 22.0 || .500 || .500 || .000 || 4.0 || 2.0 || .0 || .0 || 7.0 |- class="sortbottom" | style="text-align:left;"| Career | style="text-align:left;"| | 1 || 0 || 22.0 || .500 || .500 || .000 || 4.0 || 2.0 || .0 || .0 || 7.0 ===Euroleague=== |- | style="text-align:left;"| 2010–11 | style="text-align:left;"| Partizan Belgrade | 6 || 3 || 25.8 || .221 || .154 || .654 || 3.7 || 3.3 || 1.3 || .0 || 8.5 || 6.3 |- | style="text- align:left;"| 2011–12 | style="text-align:left;"| Asseco Prokom | 10 || 0 || 24.5 || .411 || .381 || .708 || 2.5 || 3.3 || 1.4 || .0 || 10.7 || 11.0 |- | style="text-align:left;"| 2011–12 | style="text-align:left;"| Anadolu Efes | 6 || 2 || 23.0 || .419 || .313 || .917 || 3.2 || 2.8 || 1.5 || .0 || 8.7 || 11.7 |- | style="text-align:left;"| 2012–13 | style="text-align:left;"| Zalgiris | 23 || 11 || 21.2 || .361 || .323 || .900 || 2.1 || 2.8 || .9 || .0 || 7.9 || 7.3 |- | style="text-align:left;"| 2014–15 | style="text-align:left;"| Olympiacos | 29 || 1 || 18.3 || .386 || .404 || .606 || 2.1 || 2.6 || .5 || .0 || 6.8 || 6.9 |- | style="text-align:left;"| 2015–16 | style="text- align:left;"| Milano | 10 || 3 || 22.5 || .435 || .259 || .846 || 2.0 || 2.1 || 1 || .2 || 7.3 || 5.4 |- class="sortbottom" | style="text-align:left;"| Career | style="text-align:left;"| | 74 || 17 || 21.1 || .364 || .346 || .736 || 2.4 || 2.8 || .9 || .0 || 7.9 || 8.0 === Domestic leagues === {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%; text-align:center;" !
